content.description: Wild Turkey is a nice invert problem! This can be a bit hard on the knees and shins.
content.location: It is on the northern end of Whiskey Rocks North.

climbs.name: Whiskey Crack
climbs.fa: Dean Cool, onsight with only one shoe on and a whiskey-related hangover and also after not climbing for a year

content.description:
Whiskey Crack is a classic Vedauwoo-esque offwidth and the namesake of the crag! It was the first roped climb to go up in the "Sleep" Area.... Climb the gently overhanging offwidth with a few hand/fist jams and okay footholds on the face. This is probably harder for those with smaller hands.

You can toprope this climb by going through the "Sleep" cave and scrambling up to the base of a shorter, easier OW.
content.protection: #3-#6 C4s. More wide gear is nice. There are bolts with rings up top.
content.location:
At Whiskey Rocks North..., it is to the right of "

Sleep

".

content.description: An offwidth-y start leads to some chimneying and then full body bridging at the top! This is harder if you are shorter. It has a super fun finish. There are some small, loose bits of rock in spots on this one, but it will clean up with more ascents.
content.location:
It is left of the "

Barley Made It

" Boulder.

climbs.name: Whiskey and Cheese (AKA The Drunkard's Variation)

content.description:
Start on "

Gouda Company

," but after the second bolt, start using the arete to stem, and move over into "

Whiskey Business

". It is really cool but a bit unnerving to start the stem and move into the chimney. Finish on "

Whiskey Business

".
content.location:
Start as for "

Gouda Company

."

content.description: This is a great overhanging, splitter handcrack boulder problem! Sit start for extra mileage. Heady up top.
content.location:
It is across from

Nocturnal Emission

.

content.description: This climbs a splitter OW to a squeeze. The rock quality is good, but the route is nothing special. Getting off the ground is the crux.
content.location:
It is like 3 feet right of

Unnamed Crack #69

.

content.description: I am not sure if this has been climbed! If so, go ahead, and correct me. My climbing buddy and I loved it though. It felt like we were doing the first ascent as it was very chossy down low, foot chips breaking off left and right. Anyway, start off to the left, and traverse slightly to the right to an undercling. Summit via fingers. GPS coordinates are: 39.22136,-105.33565.
content.location: In the NW section of Whiskey Rocks (North), this is one of the lower elevation boulder problems. It faces north as well.

content.description:
Sobriety Test is a really nice squeeze chimney that narrows down to hands. The topout is similar to

Plumb Line

in Vedauwoo. Don't fall or just lead it on gear.
content.location:
It is between

Wild Turkey

and

Montana Margarita

.

content.description:
The first 40-foot and crux section of

Sleep

can be bypassed by stepping across from a big boulder. The step across is kinda spooky and height-dependent, so don't fall there.
content.location:
See "

Sleep

" for details.

content.description: This is a route for the Vedauwoo fans. This absolutely stellar squeeze chimney starts all the way in the back of the cave. Jump start into an invert, and embrace the wideness. Yup, that's right, jump start! From here, worm your way inverted through the roof, pivot, squeeze your way up, and cop a good rest. Above this, it's easy chimneying with a little tough squeeze for the bigger folk near the top. It can and should be done as a boulder problem as well, and I think it is much better this way.... This is one of the best offwidths in the South Platte. The grade is very body size-dependent, favoring people with a smaller chest size.
content.protection: At least 3 pads if bouldering, if leading1x #6, 1-2x Valley Giant 9 or equivalent, optional Valley Giant 12 or equivalent. You can start the route untied and clip into the rope just after pulling the roof. There are chains up top! If doing it as a boulder problem, you can walk off with a 5th Class downclimb.
content.location: It is at Whiskey Rocks North. See the map on the main Whiskey Rocks page.

content.description:
To start, layback to the right with your fingers in the two obvious pods and your feet on seam below. Slap the arete, throw a heel, and boogie up the foot wide slab to the top.

To get down, do it all in reverse. This is the crux.
content.location:
This problem is on the sin-shaped boulder between Unnamed Crack #69/#420 and

Whiskey Business

.

content.description:
This takes the right exit of the same boulder as "

Barley Made It

".... Start on the splitter handcrack to fingercrack, and then head right to do some funky, cruxy, ultra-flared hands and finger-barring trickery until you can get a really nice handjam at the lip, then flip around over the lip using leg bars and maybe some kneebar tricks, and top out. There is really cool movement on this one! It might be a sandbag, or even soft if you can figure out how to chimney the first crux.
content.location:
It is on the same boulder as "

Barley Made It

."

content.description: Pillow Talk is another offwidth/squeeze for Whiskey Rocks. Climb easy ground, then do a little squeeze boulder problem to a rest, then finish the route to the top!
content.protection: 12" Valley Giant and 9" Valley Giant or equivalent.
content.location:
At Whiskey Rocks North, it is the first route to the left of

Sleep

.

content.description:
Climb the colorful, left-angling splitter. It gradually gets harder and is deceptively steep, and there is not much on the face for feet.... Step off on the boulder stuck in the chimney. The crack seeps after rain. This thing is a blast!

To clean, either have someone follow, or you can set an anchor up top and swing across.
content.location:
It is left of

Nocturnal Emission

.

content.description: Start on hands/fists, then invert, pivot, and top out. The topout is pretty dirty and hard to clean unfortunately, and there's a large boulder in the way of the beginning of this problem making it shorter. Otherwise, it would be pretty awesome.
content.location:
It is about 10 yards left of "

Intoxication

" in a cave.

content.description: This climbs a really sweet, albeit short, 45-degree overhanging crack. It starts as finger-size and widens. This is kind of a sporty route with a unique finish. It is easy to set a toprope, but you'll want a directional.
content.protection: Cams 0.5-2 C4 and bolts up top. It can be toproped pretty easily, just use a directional or two!
content.location:
It is way left of

Sleep

.

content.description:
To make a Montana Margarita, take a Montucky Cold Snack, remove the top with a can opener, and add some tequila and lime. Enjoy!

This is a good boulder problem with mostly hands.
content.location:
It is just south of

Wild Turkey

.

content.description: This thing is a SWEET fingercrack roof. Start with one hand underclinging the wide slot with your feet in that same slot and one hand in the fingercrack. Make some hard moves to gain the handcrack, campus until you can regain feet in the crack, and top out from there. A lower start could potentially be added making it much harder. People with smaller hands will find that they get better fingerlocks in the roof. The two boulders on either side of the roof crack are considered "off".
content.protection: Pads, spotters, and good body awareness, so you don't smack the back wall when you fall. Also, gravel likes to collect up top, so make sure your topout is clean before committing!
content.location:
Go through the chimney to the right of "

Barley Made It

," and then duck under the boulder to the right. You will enter a chamber with some boulders in it. Look up to see the crack.

content.description:
In the corridor between

Highball

and

Whiskey Business

, find a detached flake on the ground, and begin from the top of it. Once established in the chimney, work through a bulge, up past good holds, and top out.

The lower angle wall hosts some very nice edges inside and would make a proud face climb if it wasn't hidden in the cave, but then it likely would have roasted in the Hayman Fire and would have suffered the same flaky fate as the boulders outside. There is probably enough space inside to face climb without scraping the wall behind you, but a fall from the top would chop you on the detached flake below.
content.protection: The FA was solo. It is possible however to set up a very convoluded TR anchor from the analog crack on the roof of the Barley Made It Boulder using 20-30 feet of webbing.
content.location:
Facing

Whiskey Business

, look to your right and walk into the hall, then look up.

content.description: Intoxication is a really nice, long, roof-crack boulder problem that goes from squeeze chimney to hands, which slowly flare into nothingness. It has an awkward, perplexing finish and is very grovelly. This will be a classic when it cleans up.
content.location:
This is across from "

Unnamed Crack #69

" and under "

Nocturnal Emission

." Start allllll the way back in the cave.

content.description: A highball is not only a tall boulder but also a classic mixed drink. Climb the slabby face/arete, and top out. Don't fall, because there is a leg breaking boulder right underneath the climb.
content.location: Walk through the "?Speakeasy Chimney?," and look immediately left. This route climbs the west face/arete of the boulder.

content.description: A handcrack roof leads into a corner change and awkward handcrack. This will be better when it cleans up. It can also be done as a boulder problem. It is a punchy route.
content.protection: Hand-sized pieces, there is no anchor up top. Use pads if bouldering. Walk off.
content.location:
It is at Whiskey Rocks North above

Nocturnal Emission

on a hill.

content.description:
Gouda Company has nice, featured slab climbing that shares an anchor with "

Whiskey Business

".... Top out, and reach over to the shared anchors. If you cannot reach these, simply walk off. A

fall clipping the second bolt would not be advised.
content.location:
It shares an anchor with "

Whiskey Business

."

content.description: Start all the way back in the cave, and then work your way back out using chimney and squeeze technique. I guess it could be easier if you stay outside the squeeze, but it would be R/X rated this way.... The crack begins to narrow as you continue upward. This is a very cool climb and VERY overhung for 5.9!
content.protection: Big... BD #6-8 or equivalent. There is a 2 bolt anchor on top.
content.location: Walk THROUGH the "Sleep" cave, and at the end of the cave, climb up an easy 4th Class chimney, go all the way back into the cave, and then at the end of the cave, there is a room at the end containing this climb. We call this area "The Cooler", since it stays nice and cool in the summer.

content.description: Fine Cheese Club Initiation ascends a nice, less-than-vertical handcrack with a friendly topout. It is a very Gouda climb for beginner crack climbers..., but it is kinda dirty and a little sharp. You'll be very fondue of it.
content.location: It is on the very north end of the formation, the side closest to the road.

content.description: This is a good beginner lead but not necessarily a route to make the drive to. Climb up easy ground to a short offwidth into a fun but short handcrack. Those not familiar with wide technique may find they will have to work a little harder for this.
content.protection:
0.75 to #5. This shares an anchor with "

Pillow Talk

."
content.location:
This is at Whiskey Rocks North. It is left of

Pillow Talk

.

content.description: Whiskey Business is a fun slab problem! Start with your feet on the rail and your hands on crystals, and walk to the right until you can top out onto the slab, then climb easy ground to the top.
content.location:
It is on the same boulder as

Bottom of the Barrel

.

content.description:
There are 2 ways to start this: one way is to do the direct start which is a low angle offwidth. The better way is to do a right-angling splitter finger crack. Either way, you end up in a squeeze chimney that narrows down into a more difficult offwidth crux. This is a good route to prepare yourself for the more difficult OW routes in the area.

To toprope this one, you can walk around the back
content.protection: Finger-sized pieces and wide gear from a BD #4 to #6. No hand-sized gear is needed. There are bolts up top, and this can be toproped fairly easily by walking around the back side.
content.location: Walk THROUGH the "Sleep" cave, and at the end of the cave, climb up an easy 4th Class chimney, go all the way back into the cave, and then at the end of the cave, there is a room at the end containing this climb. We call this area "The Cooler", since it stays nice and cool in the summer.

content.description:
This is a sort of variation to

Cheddar Business Bureau

. Instead of starting in the nice, wide chimney, start way back in the chimney to where it starts to pinch down, squeeze upwards, then rejoin

Cheddar Business Bureau

once you reach the top where the crack closes shut. This is quality squeeze chimney climbing.
content.protection: Either good squeeze technique or a BD #7 and #8 and a purple Totem.
content.location:
It is next to

Cheddar Business Bureau

further back in the chimney....

content.description: Cheddar Business Bureau is a really awesome short chimney that is protectable with finger-sized pieces! Chimney-size is kind of an awkward in between one where you can't quite feel solid, but there are finger cracks traversing the face you can get a good foot on. The crux is near the top.
content.protection: Finger-sized pieces and an optional #7. There are bolted anchors up top but no rings, since you can walk off easily.
content.location:
Behind "

Whiskey Business

", there is a little tunnel entrance that brings you into a series of chambers and chimneys we call The Speakeasy. This route is the southernmost chimney/room.

content.description: Start on a sharp, crimpy jug, make a big move to another hold, and top out.
content.location:
It is right next to

Barley Made It

to the north.

content.description: This is Anti-Classic! Start on the east side of the boulder, then chimney, invert, and squeeze out the other side. It is hard to keep your head off the ground if you are taller. This is very weird and very enduro-y.
content.protection: None is needed, since you are so close to the ground.
content.location:
This is the boulder a few feet northeast of

Wild Turkey

.

content.description: Climb a sharp, splitter hand crack into an even sharper finger crack, then cut left and make a biiiiig reach to a hand jam, then top out using OW technique... "Rye Not?" takes the right exit on ridiculously flared hands. This is the kind of boulder that you need to bust out all the crack and face technique you have.
content.location:
It is in between

Nocturnal Emission

and

Drunk Heathens

.

content.description: This is the only offwidth in a hole I know of. Use tough armbars and stacks, top out, and be reborn on the ledge.
content.protection: Wide stuff. I remember it being #6 sized.
content.location:
It is at Whiskey Rocks North. When you cross the smallish gap to get to

Nocturnal Emission

, look down. It's the offwidth in a hole.
